speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Good Margaret, run thee to the parlor;
There shalt thou find my cousin Beatrice
Proposing with the prince and Claudio:
Whisper her ear and tell her, I and Ursula
Walk in the orchard and our whole discourse
Is all of her; say that thou overheard'st us;
And bid her steal into the pleached bower,
Where honeysuckles, ripen'd by the sun,
Forbid the sun to enter, like favourites,
Made proud by princes, that advance their pride
Against that power that bred it: there will she hide her,
To listen our purpose. This is thy office;
Bear thee well in it and leave us alone.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: I'll make her come, I warrant you, presently.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Now, Ursula, when Beatrice doth come,
As we do trace this alley up and down,
Our talk must only be of Benedick.
When I do name him, let it be thy part
To praise him more than ever man did merit:
My talk to thee must be how Benedick
Is sick in love with Beatrice. Of this matter
Is little Cupid's crafty arrow made,
That only wounds by hearsay.
Now begin;
For look where Beatrice, like a lapwing, runs
Close by the ground, to hear our conference.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: The pleasant'st angling is to see the fish
Cut with her golden oars the silver stream,
And greedily devour the treacherous bait:
So angle we for Beatrice; who even now
Is couched in the woodbine coverture.
Fear you not my part of the dialogue.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Then go we near her, that her ear lose nothing
Of the false sweet bait that we lay for it.
No, truly, Ursula, she is too disdainful;
I know her spirits are as coy and wild
As haggerds of the rock.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: But are you sure
That Benedick loves Beatrice so entirely?

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: So says the prince and my new-trothed lord.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: And did they bid you tell her of it, madam?

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: They did entreat me to acquaint her of it;
But I persuaded them, if they loved Benedick,
To wish him wrestle with affection,
And never to let Beatrice know of it.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: Why did you so? Doth not the gentleman
Deserve as full as fortunate a bed
As ever Beatrice shall couch upon?

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: O god of love! I know he doth deserve
As much as may be yielded to a man:
But Nature never framed a woman's heart
Of prouder stuff than that of Beatrice;
Disdain and scorn ride sparkling in her eyes,
Misprising what they look on, and her wit
Values itself so highly that to her
All matter else seems weak: she cannot love,
Nor take no shape nor project of affection,
She is so self-endeared.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: Sure, I think so;
And therefore certainly it were not good
She knew his love, lest she make sport at it.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Why, you speak truth. I never yet saw man,
How wise, how noble, young, how rarely featured,
But she would spell him backward: if fair-faced,
She would swear the gentleman should be her sister;
If black, why, Nature, drawing of an antique,
Made a foul blot; if tall, a lance ill-headed;
If low, an agate very vilely cut;
If speaking, why, a vane blown with all winds;
If silent, why, a block moved with none.
So turns she every man the wrong side out
And never gives to truth and virtue that
Which simpleness and merit purchaseth.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: Sure, sure, such carping is not commendable.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: No, not to be so odd and from all fashions
As Beatrice is, cannot be commendable:
But who dare tell her so? If I should speak,
She would mock me into air; O, she would laugh me
Out of myself, press me to death with wit.
Therefore let Benedick, like cover'd fire,
Consume away in sighs, waste inwardly:
It were a better death than die with mocks,
Which is as bad as die with tickling.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: Yet tell her of it: hear what she will say.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: No; rather I will go to Benedick
And counsel him to fight against his passion.
And, truly, I'll devise some honest slanders
To stain my cousin with: one doth not know
How much an ill word may empoison liking.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: O, do not do your cousin such a wrong.
She cannot be so much without true judgment--
Having so swift and excellent a wit
As she is prized to have--as to refuse
So rare a gentleman as Signior Benedick.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: He is the only man of Italy.
Always excepted my dear Claudio.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: I pray you, be not angry with me, madam,
Speaking my fancy: Signior Benedick,
For shape, for bearing, argument and valour,
Goes foremost in report through Italy.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Indeed, he hath an excellent good name.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: His excellence did earn it, ere he had it.
When are you married, madam?

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Why, every day, to-morrow. Come, go in:
I'll show thee some attires, and have thy counsel
Which is the best to furnish me to-morrow.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: She's limed, I warrant you: we have caught her, madam.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: If it proves so, then loving goes by haps:
Some Cupid kills with arrows, some with traps.

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: What fire is in mine ears? Can this be true?
Stand I condemn'd for pride and scorn so much?
Contempt, farewell! and maiden pride, adieu!
No glory lives behind the back of such.
And, Benedick, love on; I will requite thee,
Taming my wild heart to thy loving hand:
If thou dost love, my kindness shall incite thee
To bind our loves up in a holy band;
For others say thou dost deserve, and I
Believe it better than reportingly.

scene.title: SCENE II. A room in LEONATO'S house

scene-body.stagedir: Enter DON PEDRO, CLAUDIO, BENEDICK, and LEONATO

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: I do but stay till your marriage be consummate, and
then go I toward Arragon.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: I'll bring you thither, my lord, if you'll
vouchsafe me.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Nay, that would be as great a soil in the new gloss
of your marriage as to show a child his new coat
and forbid him to wear it. I will only be bold
with Benedick for his company; for, from the crown
of his head to the sole of his foot, he is all
mirth: he hath twice or thrice cut Cupid's
bow-string and the little hangman dare not shoot at
him; he hath a heart as sound as a bell and his
tongue is the clapper, for what his heart thinks his
tongue speaks.

speech.speaker: BENEDICK
speech.line: Gallants, I am not as I have been.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: So say I methinks you are sadder.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: I hope he be in love.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Hang him, truant! there's no true drop of blood in
him, to be truly touched with love: if he be sad,
he wants money.

speech.speaker: BENEDICK
speech.line: I have the toothache.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Draw it.

speech.speaker: BENEDICK
speech.line: Hang it!

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: You must hang it first, and draw it afterwards.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: What! sigh for the toothache?

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: Where is but a humour or a worm.

speech.speaker: BENEDICK
speech.line: Well, every one can master a grief but he that has
it.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: Yet say I, he is in love.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: There is no appearance of fancy in him, unless it be
a fancy that he hath to strange disguises; as, to be
a Dutchman today, a Frenchman to-morrow, or in the
shape of two countries at once, as, a German from
the waist downward, all slops, and a Spaniard from
the hip upward, no doublet. Unless he have a fancy
to this foolery, as it appears he hath, he is no
fool for fancy, as you would have it appear he is.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: If he be not in love with some woman, there is no
believing old signs: a' brushes his hat o'
mornings; what should that bode?

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Hath any man seen him at the barber's?

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: No, but the barber's man hath been seen with him,
and the old ornament of his cheek hath already
stuffed tennis-balls.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: Indeed, he looks younger than he did, by the loss of a beard.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Nay, a' rubs himself with civet: can you smell him
out by that?

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: That's as much as to say, the sweet youth's in love.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: The greatest note of it is his melancholy.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: And when was he wont to wash his face?

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Yea, or to paint himself? for the which, I hear
what they say of him.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: Nay, but his jesting spirit; which is now crept into
a lute-string and now governed by stops.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Indeed, that tells a heavy tale for him: conclude,
conclude he is in love.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: Nay, but I know who loves him.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: That would I know too: I warrant, one that knows him not.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: Yes, and his ill conditions; and, in despite of
all, dies for him.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: She shall be buried with her face upwards.

speech.speaker: BENEDICK
speech.line: Yet is this no charm for the toothache. Old
signior, walk aside with me: I have studied eight
or nine wise words to speak to you, which these
hobby-horses must not hear.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: For my life, to break with him about Beatrice.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: 'Tis even so. Hero and Margaret have by this
played their parts with Beatrice; and then the two
bears will not bite one another when they meet.

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: My lord and brother, God save you!

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Good den, brother.

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: If your leisure served, I would speak with you.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: In private?

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: If it please you: yet Count Claudio may hear; for
what I would speak of concerns him.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: What's the matter?

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: To CLAUDIO Means your lordship to be married
to-morrow?

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: You know he does.

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: I know not that, when he knows what I know.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: If there be any impediment, I pray you discover it.

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: You may think I love you not: let that appear
hereafter, and aim better at me by that I now will
manifest. For my brother, I think he holds you
well, and in dearness of heart hath holp to effect
your ensuing marriage;--surely suit ill spent and
labour ill bestowed.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Why, what's the matter?

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: I came hither to tell you; and, circumstances
shortened, for she has been too long a talking of,
the lady is disloyal.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: Who, Hero?

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: Even she; Leonato's Hero, your Hero, every man's Hero:

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: Disloyal?

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: The word is too good to paint out her wickedness; I
could say she were worse: think you of a worse
title, and I will fit her to it. Wonder not till
further warrant: go but with me to-night, you shall
see her chamber-window entered, even the night
before her wedding-day: if you love her then,
to-morrow wed her; but it would better fit your honour
to change your mind.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: May this be so?

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: I will not think it.

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: If you dare not trust that you see, confess not
that you know: if you will follow me, I will show
you enough; and when you have seen more and heard
more, proceed accordingly.

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: If I see any thing to-night why I should not marry
her to-morrow in the congregation, where I should
wed, there will I shame her.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: And, as I wooed for thee to obtain her, I will join
with thee to disgrace her.

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: I will disparage her no farther till you are my
witnesses: bear it coldly but till midnight, and
let the issue show itself.

speech.speaker: DON PEDRO
speech.line: O day untowardly turned!

speech.speaker: CLAUDIO
speech.line: O mischief strangely thwarting!

speech.speaker: DON JOHN
speech.line: O plague right well prevented! so will you say when
you have seen the sequel.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter DOGBERRY and VERGES with the Watch

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Are you good men and true?

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: Yea, or else it were pity but they should suffer
salvation, body and soul.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Nay, that were a punishment too good for them, if
they should have any allegiance in them, being
chosen for the prince's watch.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: Well, give them their charge, neighbour Dogberry.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: First, who think you the most desertless man to be
constable?

speech.speaker: First Watchman
speech.line: Hugh Otecake, sir, or George Seacole; for they can
write and read.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Come hither, neighbour Seacole. God hath blessed
you with a good name: to be a well-favoured man is
the gift of fortune; but to write and read comes by nature.

speech.speaker: Second Watchman
speech.line: Both which, master constable,--

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: You have: I knew it would be your answer. Well,
for your favour, sir, why, give God thanks, and make
no boast of it; and for your writing and reading,
let that appear when there is no need of such
vanity. You are thought here to be the most
senseless and fit man for the constable of the
watch; therefore bear you the lantern. This is your
charge: you shall comprehend all vagrom men; you are
to bid any man stand, in the prince's name.

speech.speaker: Second Watchman
speech.line: How if a' will not stand?

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Why, then, take no note of him, but let him go; and
presently call the rest of the watch together and
thank God you are rid of a knave.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: If he will not stand when he is bidden, he is none
of the prince's subjects.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: True, and they are to meddle with none but the
prince's subjects. You shall also make no noise in
the streets; for, for the watch to babble and to
talk is most tolerable and not to be endured.

speech.speaker: Watchman
speech.line: We will rather sleep than talk: we know what
belongs to a watch.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Why, you speak like an ancient and most quiet
watchman; for I cannot see how sleeping should
offend: only, have a care that your bills be not
stolen. Well, you are to call at all the
ale-houses, and bid those that are drunk get them to bed.

speech.speaker: Watchman
speech.line: How if they will not?

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Why, then, let them alone till they are sober: if
they make you not then the better answer, you may
say they are not the men you took them for.

speech.speaker: Watchman
speech.line: Well, sir.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: If you meet a thief, you may suspect him, by virtue
of your office, to be no true man; and, for such
kind of men, the less you meddle or make with them,
why the more is for your honesty.

speech.speaker: Watchman
speech.line: If we know him to be a thief, shall we not lay
hands on him?

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Truly, by your office, you may; but I think they
that touch pitch will be defiled: the most peaceable
way for you, if you do take a thief, is to let him
show himself what he is and steal out of your company.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: You have been always called a merciful man, partner.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Truly, I would not hang a dog by my will, much more
a man who hath any honesty in him.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: If you hear a child cry in the night, you must call
to the nurse and bid her still it.

speech.speaker: Watchman
speech.line: How if the nurse be asleep and will not hear us?

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Why, then, depart in peace, and let the child wake
her with crying; for the ewe that will not hear her
lamb when it baes will never answer a calf when he bleats.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: 'Tis very true.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: This is the end of the charge:--you, constable, are
to present the prince's own person: if you meet the
prince in the night, you may stay him.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: Nay, by'r our lady, that I think a' cannot.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Five shillings to one on't, with any man that knows
the statutes, he may stay him: marry, not without
the prince be willing; for, indeed, the watch ought
to offend no man; and it is an offence to stay a
man against his will.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: By'r lady, I think it be so.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha! Well, masters, good night: an there be
any matter of weight chances, call up me: keep your
fellows' counsels and your own; and good night.
Come, neighbour.

speech.speaker: Watchman
speech.line: Well, masters, we hear our charge: let us go sit here
upon the church-bench till two, and then all to bed.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: One word more, honest neighbours. I pray you watch
about Signior Leonato's door; for the wedding being
there to-morrow, there is a great coil to-night.
Adieu: be vigitant, I beseech you.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: What Conrade!

speech.speaker: Watchman
speech.line: Aside Peace! stir not.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Conrade, I say!

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: Here, man; I am at thy elbow.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Mass, and my elbow itched; I thought there would a
scab follow.

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: I will owe thee an answer for that: and now forward
with thy tale.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Stand thee close, then, under this pent-house, for
it drizzles rain; and I will, like a true drunkard,
utter all to thee.

speech.speaker: Watchman
speech.line: Aside Some treason, masters: yet stand close.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Therefore know I have earned of Don John a thousand ducats.

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: Is it possible that any villany should be so dear?

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Thou shouldst rather ask if it were possible any
villany should be so rich; for when rich villains
have need of poor ones, poor ones may make what
price they will.

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: I wonder at it.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: That shows thou art unconfirmed. Thou knowest that
the fashion of a doublet, or a hat, or a cloak, is
nothing to a man.

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: Yes, it is apparel.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: I mean, the fashion.

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: Yes, the fashion is the fashion.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Tush! I may as well say the fool's the fool. But
seest thou not what a deformed thief this fashion
is?

speech.speaker: Watchman
speech.line: Aside I know that Deformed; a' has been a vile
thief this seven year; a' goes up and down like a
gentleman: I remember his name.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Didst thou not hear somebody?

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: No; 'twas the vane on the house.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Seest thou not, I say, what a deformed thief this
fashion is? how giddily a' turns about all the hot
bloods between fourteen and five-and-thirty?
sometimes fashioning them like Pharaoh's soldiers
in the reeky painting, sometime like god Bel's
priests in the old church-window, sometime like the
shaven Hercules in the smirched worm-eaten tapestry,
where his codpiece seems as massy as his club?

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: All this I see; and I see that the fashion wears
out more apparel than the man. But art not thou
thyself giddy with the fashion too, that thou hast
shifted out of thy tale into telling me of the fashion?

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Not so, neither: but know that I have to-night
wooed Margaret, the Lady Hero's gentlewoman, by the
name of Hero: she leans me out at her mistress'
chamber-window, bids me a thousand times good
night,--I tell this tale vilely:--I should first
tell thee how the prince, Claudio and my master,
planted and placed and possessed by my master Don
John, saw afar off in the orchard this amiable encounter.

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: And thought they Margaret was Hero?

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: Two of them did, the prince and Claudio; but the
devil my master knew she was Margaret; and partly
by his oaths, which first possessed them, partly by
the dark night, which did deceive them, but chiefly
by my villany, which did confirm any slander that
Don John had made, away went Claudio enraged; swore
he would meet her, as he was appointed, next morning
at the temple, and there, before the whole
congregation, shame her with what he saw o'er night
and send her home again without a husband.

speech.speaker: First Watchman
speech.line: We charge you, in the prince's name, stand!

speech.speaker: Second Watchman
speech.line: Call up the right master constable. We have here
recovered the most dangerous piece of lechery that
ever was known in the commonwealth.

speech.speaker: First Watchman
speech.line: And one Deformed is one of them: I know him; a'
wears a lock.

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: Masters, masters,--

speech.speaker: Second Watchman
speech.line: You'll be made bring Deformed forth, I warrant you.

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: Masters,--

speech.speaker: First Watchman
speech.line: Never speak: we charge you let us obey you to go with us.

speech.speaker: BORACHIO
speech.line: We are like to prove a goodly commodity, being taken
up of these men's bills.

speech.speaker: CONRADE
speech.line: A commodity in question, I warrant you. Come, we'll obey you.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Good Ursula, wake my cousin Beatrice, and desire
her to rise.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: I will, lady.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: And bid her come hither.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: Well.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: Troth, I think your other rabato were better.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: No, pray thee, good Meg, I'll wear this.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: By my troth, 's not so good; and I warrant your
cousin will say so.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: My cousin's a fool, and thou art another: I'll wear
none but this.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: I like the new tire within excellently, if the hair
were a thought browner; and your gown's a most rare
fashion, i' faith. I saw the Duchess of Milan's
gown that they praise so.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: O, that exceeds, they say.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: By my troth, 's but a night-gown in respect of
yours: cloth o' gold, and cuts, and laced with
silver, set with pearls, down sleeves, side sleeves,
and skirts, round underborne with a bluish tinsel:
but for a fine, quaint, graceful and excellent
fashion, yours is worth ten on 't.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: God give me joy to wear it! for my heart is
exceeding heavy.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: 'Twill be heavier soon by the weight of a man.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Fie upon thee! art not ashamed?

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: Of what, lady? of speaking honourably? Is not
marriage honourable in a beggar? Is not your lord
honourable without marriage? I think you would have
me say, 'saving your reverence, a husband:' and bad
thinking do not wrest true speaking, I'll offend
nobody: is there any harm in 'the heavier for a
husband'? None, I think, and it be the right husband
and the right wife; otherwise 'tis light, and not
heavy: ask my Lady Beatrice else; here she comes.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Good morrow, coz.

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: Good morrow, sweet Hero.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Why how now? do you speak in the sick tune?

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: I am out of all other tune, methinks.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: Clap's into 'Light o' love;' that goes without a
burden: do you sing it, and I'll dance it.

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: Ye light o' love, with your heels! then, if your
husband have stables enough, you'll see he shall
lack no barns.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: O illegitimate construction! I scorn that with my heels.

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: 'Tis almost five o'clock, cousin; tis time you were
ready. By my troth, I am exceeding ill: heigh-ho!

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: For a hawk, a horse, or a husband?

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: For the letter that begins them all, H.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: Well, and you be not turned Turk, there's no more
sailing by the star.

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: What means the fool, trow?

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: Nothing I; but God send every one their heart's desire!

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: These gloves the count sent me; they are an
excellent perfume.

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: I am stuffed, cousin; I cannot smell.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: A maid, and stuffed! there's goodly catching of cold.

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: O, God help me! God help me! how long have you
professed apprehension?

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: Even since you left it. Doth not my wit become me rarely?

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: It is not seen enough, you should wear it in your
cap. By my troth, I am sick.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: Get you some of this distilled Carduus Benedictus,
and lay it to your heart: it is the only thing for a qualm.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: There thou prickest her with a thistle.

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: Benedictus! why Benedictus? you have some moral in
this Benedictus.

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: Moral! no, by my troth, I have no moral meaning; I
meant, plain holy-thistle. You may think perchance
that I think you are in love: nay, by'r lady, I am
not such a fool to think what I list, nor I list
not to think what I can, nor indeed I cannot think,
if I would think my heart out of thinking, that you
are in love or that you will be in love or that you
can be in love. Yet Benedick was such another, and
now is he become a man: he swore he would never
marry, and yet now, in despite of his heart, he eats
his meat without grudging: and how you may be
converted I know not, but methinks you look with
your eyes as other women do.

speech.speaker: BEATRICE
speech.line: What pace is this that thy tongue keeps?

speech.speaker: MARGARET
speech.line: Not a false gallop.

speech.speaker: URSULA
speech.line: Madam, withdraw: the prince, the count, Signior
Benedick, Don John, and all the gallants of the
town, are come to fetch you to church.

speech.speaker: HERO
speech.line: Help to dress me, good coz, good Meg, good Ursula.

scene.title: SCENE V. Another room in LEONATO'S house.

scene-body.stagedir: Enter LEONATO, with DOGBERRY and VERGES

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: What would you with me, honest neighbour?

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Marry, sir, I would have some confidence with you
that decerns you nearly.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: Brief, I pray you; for you see it is a busy time with me.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Marry, this it is, sir.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: Yes, in truth it is, sir.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: What is it, my good friends?

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Goodman Verges, sir, speaks a little off the
matter: an old man, sir, and his wits are not so
blunt as, God help, I would desire they were; but,
in faith, honest as the skin between his brows.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: Yes, I thank God I am as honest as any man living
that is an old man and no honester than I.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Comparisons are odorous: palabras, neighbour Verges.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: Neighbours, you are tedious.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: It pleases your worship to say so, but we are the
poor duke's officers; but truly, for mine own part,
if I were as tedious as a king, I could find it in
my heart to bestow it all of your worship.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: All thy tediousness on me, ah?

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Yea, an 'twere a thousand pound more than 'tis; for
I hear as good exclamation on your worship as of any
man in the city; and though I be but a poor man, I
am glad to hear it.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: And so am I.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: I would fain know what you have to say.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: Marry, sir, our watch to-night, excepting your
worship's presence, ha' ta'en a couple of as arrant
knaves as any in Messina.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: A good old man, sir; he will be talking: as they
say, when the age is in, the wit is out: God help
us! it is a world to see. Well said, i' faith,
neighbour Verges: well, God's a good man; an two men
ride of a horse, one must ride behind. An honest
soul, i' faith, sir; by my troth he is, as ever
broke bread; but God is to be worshipped; all men
are not alike; alas, good neighbour!

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: Indeed, neighbour, he comes too short of you.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Gifts that God gives.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: I must leave you.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: One word, sir: our watch, sir, have indeed
comprehended two aspicious persons, and we would
have them this morning examined before your worship.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: Take their examination yourself and bring it me: I
am now in great haste, as it may appear unto you.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: It shall be suffigance.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: Drink some wine ere you go: fare you well.

speech.speaker: Messenger
speech.line: My lord, they stay for you to give your daughter to
her husband.

speech.speaker: LEONATO
speech.line: I'll wait upon them: I am ready.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: Go, good partner, go, get you to Francis Seacole;
bid him bring his pen and inkhorn to the gaol: we
are now to examination these men.

speech.speaker: VERGES
speech.line: And we must do it wisely.

speech.speaker: DOGBERRY
speech.line: We will spare for no wit, I warrant you; here's
that shall drive some of them to a non-come: only
get the learned writer to set down our
excommunication and meet me at the gaol.
